generationDetails.description: Questions generated automatically from teacher-facing lesson overviews and NSW Stage 2 outcomes to sample recall, understanding and application across all five lessons.

questions.question: Which statement BEST describes Earth’s mantle?

answers.content: A thin, brittle layer of solid rock that we live on.
answers.explanation: This is the crust, not the mantle.

answers.content: A thick zone of semi-solid rock that slowly convects beneath the crust.
answers.explanation: Convection currents in the semi-solid mantle drive plate movement.

answers.content: A ball of solid iron and nickel kept solid by pressure.
answers.explanation: That is the inner core.

answers.content: A layer of liquid water between the crust and core.
answers.explanation: There is no liquid-water layer inside Earth.

questions.question: Name the four main layers of the Earth in order from the outside in.

answers.content: Crust, mantle, outer core, inner core

questions.question: What causal connective did you practise using to explain the effects of an earthquake on the landscape? Write one sentence that uses it correctly.

answers.content: so
answers.explanation: Example sentence: "The earthquake struck, so the coast rose by two metres."

questions.question: During a volcanic eruption, magma that reaches Earth’s surface is called …

answers.content: lava
answers.explanation: Magma becomes lava once it erupts.

answers.content: ash
answers.explanation: Ash refers to tiny fragments of rock, not molten rock.

answers.content: sediment
answers.explanation: Sediment is weathered material carried by water or wind.

answers.content: crust
answers.explanation: The crust is the outer solid shell of Earth.

questions.question: State one constructive (creative) and one destructive effect that volcanic eruptions can have on landscapes.

answers.content: Constructive: create new land / fertile soil. Destructive: bury towns / destroy forests.

questions.question: Give ONE example of how living things (plants or animals) can cause weathering of rocks.

answers.content: Plant roots grow into cracks and pry rocks apart / tree roots widen cracks.

questions.question: In the slope-tray investigation, the greatest amount of sand was carried when the tray was …

answers.content: flat on the table.
answers.explanation: Little gravitational pull, slow water, minimal erosion.

answers.content: raised on one book (gentle slope).
answers.explanation: Some erosion but not the greatest.

answers.content: raised on three books (steep slope).
answers.explanation: Steeper slope = faster water = more erosive force.

answers.content: covered with dry sand only.
answers.explanation: Dry sand alone was not tested for erosion in the investigation.

questions.question: Explain why faster-moving water has greater power to erode rock or soil. Use the terms ‘force’ and ‘energy’ in your answer.

answers.content: Faster water has more kinetic energy, so the force it applies to rocks and soil is greater, enabling it to pick up and carry more material away.
